channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Controversial quantum-computing paper gets hefty correction — but concerns linger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02587-7

The journal Science has lifted an expression of concern on a paper claiming evidence of Majorana quasiparticles and added new details.
item.dc:title: Controversial quantum-computing paper gets hefty correction — but concerns linger
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: Publisher Correction: Liquid–liquid interfacial tension stabilized Li-metal batteries

Publisher Correction: Liquid–liquid interfacial tension stabilized Li-metal batteries

item.title: Delocalized electrolyte design enables 600 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> lithium metal pouch cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09382-4

Lithium metal battery performance is optimized using a delocalized electrolyte design that induces a disordered solvation microenvironment, thereby combining the advantages of the solvent-dominated and anion-dominated structures of conventional electrolytes.
item.dc:title: Delocalized electrolyte design enables 600 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> lithium metal pouch cells
item.dc:creator: He Huang

item.title: n-Type thermoelectric elastomers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09387-z

A microphase crosslinking strategy, leveraging aziridine-based crosslinkers, is used to render organic thermoelectric materials stretchable and elastic.
item.dc:title: n-Type thermoelectric elastomers
